content.title: Hereditary Spherocytosis
content.summary: Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is the most common inherited hemolytic anemia in people of Northern European descent, caused by defects in red blood cell membrane proteins (spectrin, ankyrin, band 3, or protein 4.2). The resulting membrane instability causes RBCs to lose membrane surface area, becoming spherical and less deformable, leading to splenic sequestration and extravascular hemolysis.
key_points: Most common inherited hemolytic anemia in Northern Europeans
Autosomal dominant (75%) or recessive; caused by membrane protein defects
Spherocytes on peripheral smear with NEGATIVE Coombs test
Osmotic fragility test and eosin-5-maleimide (EMA) binding test diagnostic
Splenectomy is curative for hemolysis (but infection risk)
content.statement: Hereditary spherocytosis is an inherited RBC membrane disorder causing chronic hemolytic anemia characterized by spherocytes, splenomegaly, and negative Coombs test, definitively treated by splenectomy.

explanation.intuition: Think of the RBC membrane as a flexible tent held up by spectrin poles attached to ankyrin stakes. In HS, defective poles or stakes make the tent unstable. The RBC loses membrane patches as it circulates, shrinking from a biconcave disc to a tight sphere that can't squeeze through splenic sinusoids.
explanation.key_insight: The negative Coombs test distinguishes hereditary spherocytosis from autoimmune hemolytic anemia - both show spherocytes, but HS has no antibodies on the RBC surface. Family history is key.
explanation.technical_details: Membrane proteins affected: spectrin-α (SPTA1), spectrin-β (SPTB), ankyrin (ANK1, most common), band 3 (SLC4A1), protein 4.2 (EPB42). Loss of vertical linkage between membrane skeleton and lipid bilayer leads to membrane vesiculation and surface area loss.

definitions_glossary.spectrin: Cytoskeletal protein forming meshwork under RBC membrane; α and β subunits
definitions_glossary.ankyrin: Protein linking spectrin to band 3 transmembrane protein; most commonly mutated in HS
definitions_glossary.band_3: Anion exchanger (AE1) protein; transmembrane anchor for cytoskeleton
definitions_glossary.spherocyte: Small, round RBC lacking central pallor due to loss of surface area
definitions_glossary.osmotic_fragility_test: Historical test showing increased RBC lysis in hypotonic solutions
definitions_glossary.EMA_binding_test: Flow cytometry test using eosin-5-maleimide; reduced binding in HS
definitions_glossary.extravascular_hemolysis: RBC destruction in spleen due to inability to pass through sinusoids
definitions_glossary.MCHC: Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration; elevated in HS (>36 g/dL)
definitions_glossary.reticulocytosis: Elevated immature RBCs indicating bone marrow compensation
definitions_glossary.pigment_gallstones: Bilirubin gallstones from chronic hemolysis; common in HS
definitions_glossary.aplastic_crisis: Temporary cessation of RBC production, often triggered by parvovirus B19

pathophysiology.mechanism: Membrane protein deficiency → Vertical membrane linkage defects → Membrane vesiculation → Reduced surface area to volume ratio → Spherocyte formation → Splenic trapping and destruction

genetics.inheritance: Autosomal dominant (75%), autosomal recessive (20%), de novo (5%)

clinical_features: Family history of anemia, jaundice, splenectomy, or gallstones

CBC: Mild to moderate anemia (Hgb 9-12 g/dL typically)

confirmatory_tests.EMA_binding_test: Reduced fluorescence by flow cytometry - test of choice
confirmatory_tests.osmotic_fragility: Increased lysis in hypotonic saline (less used now)
confirmatory_tests.cryohemolysis_test: Increased lysis at 0°C in hypertonic glycerol
confirmatory_tests.genetic_testing: For atypical cases or family planning

complications: Pigment (bilirubin) gallstones - occur in >50% by adulthood
Aplastic crisis - parvovirus B19 infection stops RBC production
Megaloblastic crisis - folate depletion from chronic hemolysis

conservative.folic_acid: 1 mg daily to prevent megaloblastic crisis
conservative.transfusion: For severe anemia or aplastic crisis

splenectomy.timing: After age 5 years if possible (infection risk higher in young children)
splenectomy.approach: Laparoscopic preferred; consider partial splenectomy in children
pre_procedure: Vaccinate against S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, N. meningitidis
splenectomy.outcome: Curative for hemolysis; spherocytes persist but survive normally

post_splenectomy.prophylaxis: Daily penicillin for at least 5 years in children
post_splenectomy.education: Seek urgent care for fever; lifelong risk of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI)

definition.@value: An inherited hemolytic anemia caused by defects in red blood cell membrane proteins leading to spherocyte formation, splenic sequestration, and chronic extravascular hemolysis

scopeNote.@value: Distinguished from autoimmune hemolytic anemia by negative Coombs test

learning_objectives: Describe the molecular basis of hereditary spherocytosis
Explain how membrane defects lead to spherocyte formation and hemolysis
Differentiate hereditary spherocytosis from autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Identify diagnostic tests including EMA binding test
Outline indications for and management around splenectomy
clinical_pearls: Spherocytes + negative Coombs = think hereditary spherocytosis
Elevated MCHC (>36 g/dL) is nearly pathognomonic for HS
EMA binding test is preferred over osmotic fragility for diagnosis
Splenectomy cures hemolysis - spherocytes persist but survive normally
Vaccinate before splenectomy and give prophylactic penicillin after
Parvovirus B19 causes aplastic crisis - reticulocytes disappear
common_misconceptions: Spherocytes are diagnostic of AIHA - also seen in hereditary spherocytosis
Osmotic fragility is the gold standard - EMA binding is now preferred
Splenectomy eliminates spherocytes - they persist but no longer hemolyze
